summary: This is a U.S. District Court decision and order denying bail and remanding Jeffrey Epstein pending trial. The court reviews arguments from the prosecution and defense, applies the legal presumption of detention for sex trafficking charges involving minors, and finds clear and convincing evidence that Epstein poses a danger to the community and a risk of flight. This is a court document (likely a detention order or memorandum) filed on July 18, 2019, arguing for the pretrial detention of Jeffrey Epstein. It details evidence of his danger to the community and risk of flight, citing the 2019 search of his mansion, his past convictions, witness intimidation, and non-compliance with sex offender registration. This is a court order and opinion from Judge Richard M. Berman denying Jeffrey Epstein's motion for pretrial release and granting the government's motion for detention. The judge details the reasons for detention, citing Epstein's extreme flight risk and danger to the community, based on his vast wealth, international travel, possession of a foreign passport under an alias, history of witness tampering, and the strength of the government's evidence.

events.title: Grand Jury Indictment
events.description: A grand jury voted to indict Jeffrey Epstein on charges of conspiracy to commit sex trafficking and sex trafficking of minor girls.

events.title: Arraignment and Bail Hearing
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arraigned before Magistrate Judge Henry Pittman. The court held a bail hearing regarding his pretrial detention.

events.title: Bail Hearing Victim Testimony
events.description: The court heard testimony from two alleged victims of Jeffrey Epstein, who were minors at the time of the alleged abuse, expressing fear for their safety if he were released.

events.title: Florida State Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty in Florida state court to one count of procuring a person under 18 for prostitution and one count of solicitation of prostitution, resulting in sex offender registration.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida regarding investigations into abuse of minor girls.

events.title: Search of Epstein's NYC Mansion
events.description: FBI conducted an authorized search of Jeffrey Epstein's East 71st Street mansion in New York City, uncovering a vast trove of sexually suggestive photographs of nude underage girls and women.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Conviction
events.description: Epstein was convicted in Florida of procuring a person under 18 for prostitution (felony) and solicitation of prostitution (felony).

events.title: SORA Hearing Before Judge Pickholz
events.description: New York State Supreme Court hearing where Epstein's application to reduce his sex offender status from Level III to Level I was firmly denied by Judge Ruth Pickholz.

events.title: Payments to Potential Co-conspirators
events.description: Following the Miami Herald's investigative report, Epstein made a $100,000 payment to a company run by Individual I and a $250,000 payment to Individual II, which the government infers were attempts to influence potential witnesses.

events.title: Witness Intimidation Report
events.description: A Palm Beach Police Incident Report states an Epstein representative told a victim, "Those who help [Epstein] will be compensated and those who hurt [Epstein] will be dealt with," and offered monetary compensation for not cooperating with law enforcement.

events.title: Plea Discussions on Witness Tampering
events.description: Email discussions between Florida federal prosecutors and Epstein's attorneys about Epstein potentially pleading guilty to witness tampering, harassment, and/or obstruction of justice related to the Florida investigation.

events.title: Bail Hearing

keyFacts: The court finds clear and convincing evidence that Jeffrey Epstein poses a danger to the community and a risk of flight, leading to his pretrial detention.
Epstein is charged under federal statutes 18 U.S.C. ยง 1591 (sex trafficking) and ยง 371 (conspiracy), with allegations involving minor girls as young as 14 from 2002 to 2005.
The defense proposed a 14-condition bail package including home detention, electronic monitoring, and financial pledges from his brother Mark Epstein and friend David Mitchell.
The government presented evidence of suspicious payments in 2018 to individuals named as potential co-conspirators shortly after media reports re-emerged.
Two alleged victims testified at the bail hearing, expressing fear for their safety and the safety of other potential victims if Epstein were released.

During the July 6-7, 2019 search of Epstein's NYC mansion, the FBI found a 'vast trove' or 'substantial collection' of sexually suggestive photographs of nude underage girls and women, including CDs with labels like 'Young [Redacted Name] + [Redacted Name]' and 'Girl pics nude.'

The government alleges Epstein or his representatives intimidated witnesses during the 2006 Florida investigation, with one report quoting a representative saying, "Those who help [Epstein] will be compensated and those who hurt [Epstein] will be dealt with."

In late 2018, soon after the Miami Herald report, Epstein paid $100,000 to a potential co-conspirator (Individual I) and $250,000 to another (Individual II), which the government contends was an attempt to influence potential witnesses.

Despite being a Level III sex offender in New York required to report every 90 days, a July 10, 2019 New York Post article reported Epstein had never reported to NYPD, contradicting defense claims of 'perfect compliance.'

The U.S. Pretrial Services Department recommended Epstein's continued remand, concluding he was both a danger to the community and a flight risk, citing the nature of the charges, his criminal history, and his extensive foreign travel and assets.
The court found Jeffrey Epstein to be a severe flight risk and danger to the community, denying him bail and ordering pretrial detention.

Law enforcement seized an expired Austrian passport bearing Epstein's photo but another name from his New York home, with stamps indicating travel to France, Spain, the UK, and Saudi Arabia in the 1980s.
Epstein's asset summary listed total assets of approximately $559 million, including over $56 million in cash, and a safe in his home contained over $70,000 in cash and 48 loose diamonds.
The document references Epstein's prior guilty plea to state felonies in Florida, his status as a registered sex offender in multiple jurisdictions, and allegations of witness tampering.
The indictment includes a forfeiture allegation for property used to facilitate the offenses, specifically the New York City residence at 9 East 71st Street.
